Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Transmedia publishing platform and service system
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project will benefit news and broad media consumers, as well as the publishing and printing industries. The project augments print publications with digital interactive media content, both curated and created collaboratively by users. Media rich reading experience will enhance interest in reading and news media consumption. The data obtained during the project may lead to new approaches on engaging different audiences with news media consumption. The project?s commercial impact stems from extending the viability of print media communication industry by both improving reader retention and increasing circulation. A larger audience and the ability to closely target a market based on hard data increases revenue from advertising. Corporations and their advertising agencies will benefit by providing more relevant advertising to end users, delivering more impact per dollar spent.

This I-Corps project uses Augmented Reality to integrate multiple information channels including both physical print and digital media. The digital media assets are hosted on a server and accessed by users through an adaptive interface that selectively displays controls based on the available content and user preferences. Scanned publication pages are classified using a machine learning algorithm trained on a document database and further identified using image matching to allow necessary efficiency and precision. The system collects usage data and interaction history to learn about reading habits and media interaction. These data are used for analytics and also as an input for the image matching workflow. The prototype was developed using iterative user-centered design and tested in experiments for preferred functionality and user experience.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Despite recognized advantages of print medium in publications: physicality/tangibility, portability, unique sensory qualities, its association with more effective reading comprehension and information retention, publishers face a downward trend in demand for printed material, including newspapers and periodicals. This is related to a fundamental change in the way that people communicate and seek information, and limitations of print in supporting people's communication desires: interactivity, timely updates, and integration with web and social media.

In the 1.5-years of this I-Corps project, the Rochester Institute of Technology team developed and tested a prototype of a transmedia publishing system that uses Augmented Reality to integrate multiple information channels, including both physical print and digital media, as a means to overcome print limitations. This platform enables a media rich reading experience leading to a renewed interest in reading and news media consumption and  therefore, increases exposure to news media communications. The functionality allows print media end users to access and interact with multiple digital media forms and make entries to social media.

During the course of this I-Corps project, a customer discovery process was used and potential customers of the system were interviewed to accumulate data regarding publishing customer and end-user needs, and to assess commercial viability of the system. The requirements formulated based on the customer research were applied to the system prototype design and implementation. The team formed a start-up company to pursue commercialization of the technology. 

The intellectual merit lies in the development of a machine learning approach to classify publication pages which can be applied to continuously updated large volume databases. The broader impact of this project stems from extending the viability of print media communication industry by both improving reader retention and increasing circulation. Readers interested in printed magazines and other publications will experience more captivating and effective exposure to content, which is particularly important for engaging young people with news media. Exposure to news correlates with higher political knowledge and civic and political engagement, which, in turn, enhances psychosocial well-being. The printing industry will be positively impacted because of the increased circulation and revenue from advertising based on data analytics, wherein corporations and their advertising agencies benefit by providing more relevant advertising to end users.
